Emergency Funds are a great way to ensure you do not run out of money if you temporarily lose a job, get sick or need some money for a replacement car. This does NOT replace a savings account, and you are not supposed to touch this until you are really in an emergency.
To calculate this, you will need a rough idea of your weekly expenses

Paying off credit card debt is a geat step to being more financially secure. Make note of your interest rate and principal amount. The more you pay off the principal, the less interest you get charged.
To calculate this, you will need to find out a few things such as the interest rate in percentage terms, the monthly minimum repayment, any annual fees and how much you think you could pay off.

Credit cards utilise compound interest to their advantage. You too can utilise compound interest. With this calculator, you will be able to see just how much your money can grow.
To calculate this, you will need to know the amount you wish to invest, for how long you wish to onvest it, and if the interest if calculated daily, monthly or yearly.

Irregular payments are often categorised as payments that happen once per year. It is common to forget that car registration is due at a particular part of the year. This calcuator helps you budget by taking the overall amount and breaking it down so you can budget the entire amount over the year instead of trying to find a lump sum once a year.
To calculate this, you will need to know the amount you expect to pay in a lump sum e.g. a car registration or drivers licence payment.
